data.title: Great concert theatre
data.text: We often attend a Symphoria concert at the Civic Center.  The acoustics are wonderful and I don't think there is a bad seat in the house.

data.title: 3 Doors Down Concert
data.text:
The civic center is a surprising good place for a concert. The acoustics are great and the seating and facilities are perfect. 
Here's my tip for you...if you can- get seats in the private balconies! Seats 1-4 are the front row. The seats are wheeled office type seats, and these may be the best vantage points in the house. Not your thing? That's ok- rows A, D, and G have extra legroom. Not inches, but like a whole foot of extra space! 
Do yourself a favor and see a concert at the Civic center!

data.title: older venue
data.text: The building is getting old by other standards, but has a well lain out floor plan for a variety of convention and entertainment functions

data.title: Nice theater to watch plays
data.text: I have seen numerous Broadway plays at this theater. There is no bad seat. They host part of the annual Broadway series in Syracuse. Parking can be difficult at times.

data.title: Good
data.text: Your experience will depend entirely on the performance/play that is being performed but the seats are comfortable and the view of the stage is quite good.

data.title: No bad seats
data.text: I have attended a number of plays in the auditorium.   While it is a large venue, even the seats in the rear of the balcony have a clear view of the stage and the sound system is very good.

data.title: Venue A Bit Too Large To Fully Enjoy Broadway Productions
data.text:
I've attended many shows here, as a "Broadway In Syracuse" season ticket subscriber. In fact, in spite of what I'm about to write, I've already subscribed to next year's performances.

The shows are typically excellent, and I appreciate being able to see great musical theater in Syracuse.  The problem is the venue is just too large for many of the patrons to actually be able to really enjoy the shows. There's a reason Broadway theaters aren't huge: it's so that the audience members can actually be close enough to the actors to see the expressions on their faces. That's not really possible from many of the seats in the back of the orchestra section at this theater.

I don't have a solution, of course. My suggestion, if you are purchasing individual tickets to shows here, would be to opt for tickets closer, and on the sides, rather than being further back, and more centered, as further back really can be just too far back.
